Popular Problems flies by, with only nine songs in 36 minutes. Yet the music creates a space for reflection that expands with each listen. Produced by and co-written with Patrick Leonard, known for his work on many of MadonnaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s best albums, Popular Problems lands musically somewhere between CohenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s synthesizer-heavy excursions of the early 2000s and his wonderfully varied 2012 album Old Ideas. A full band appears in most tracks, but others are just Cohen and Leonard enjoying a dialogue in the studio, augmented by the ubiquitous backing singers who have long represented CohenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s anima and muse.

As he did with Old Ideas, Cohen places his poetry within enriching but unobtrusive frameworks. The slinky Ã¢â‚¬Å“My Oh MyÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ sounds a bit like CohenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s fellow Canadian, Neil Young. Some songs are spare; none push. CohenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s vocals, mostly recitations but sometimes (as in the hymn-like Ã¢â‚¬Å“Did I Ever Love YouÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½) swelling to a full growl, are the life force around which Leonard builds his scene.

The singerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charisma is in fine form as he shares reflections on how shattering yet widely shared external events Ã¢â‚¬â€ popular problems Ã¢â‚¬â€ temper the spirit like heat on cast iron. As he often does, Cohen also reaches into sacred texts for inspiration Ã¢â‚¬â€ especially in Ã¢â‚¬Å“Born In Chains,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ an expansion on Exodus that also reflects his Zen training. The ease which which that song unfolds belies the fact that it took Cohen decades to write.

CohenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s serious subject matter never becomes ponderous Ã¢â‚¬â€ or, heaven forbid, tiresomely topical Ã¢â‚¬â€ because heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s always sitting there in the middle of it with his wit, his lusts, and his hard-earned equanimity. Take it slow, Popular Problems advises. It gives you more of a chance to get things close to right.
